awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Efficient Privacy-aware Document Search in the Cloud
awd_abstract_narration:
As sensitive information is increasingly stored in the cloud, privacy protection is a critical factor for users to adopt cloud-based information services such as document search. A cloud server can observe the client-initiated query processing flow, extract statistical patterns, and reason about client's data. As a result, the risk of leakage-abuse attacks exists when searching in the cloud. The main challenge to perform privacy-preserving search is that index visitation can reveal sensitive data patterns, and computation involved in advanced ranking can further expose private feature information.  On the other hand, hiding index and feature information through full encryption prevents the server from performing effective scoring and result comparison. This project explores the challenging open problems in algorithmic indexing and ranking solutions for privacy-aware cloud data search. The approach emphasizes an evaluation-driven design where search performance is assessed in multiple aspects of relevance, efficiency, and privacy for practical system deployment. The project integrates the proposed research with an educational plan including undergraduate and graduate students' involvement in the research project, instructional material development, and outreach activities.

The exploratory research addresses two fundamental research challenges: (1) privacy-aware indexing and runtime support in matching documents for a given query with an emphasis to curtail statistical text information leakage while providing efficient and private access of ranking features; (2) privacy-aware end-to-end top-K ranking with a multi-stage scheme which seeks a combination of linear and nonlinear methods such as neural nets and learning ensembles. The design goal is to minimize the leakage of document features and characteristics while still accomplishing a reasonable response time and competitive relevance. The evaluation process will use public datasets to assess the effectiveness of the developed techniques for practical system deployment.  This research effort will open the door for bridging the gap between privacy and advanced information retrieval in searching large encrypted datasets. The developed research results will be made public for research and industry communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main task of this project includes the investigation of privacy-aware indexing and runtime support in matching documents for a given query, and the design goal is to minimize the leakage of document features and characteristics while still accomplishing a reasonable response time and effective search relevance.  The project has also studied fast algorithms for efficient multi-stage search on a large dataset with neural document ranking.

The project has explored privacy-aware document retrieval for multi-keyword document search in a trusted hardware execution environment such as Intel SGX. The previous work uses time-consuming oblivious computing techniques to avoid the leakage of memory access patterns. Our work proposes a new design that obfuscates the inverted index structure with posting bucketing and document ID masking, to hide document-term association and avoid the access pattern leakage. The advantage of this work is corroborated by a privacy and efficiency analysis.  Our evaluation shows the proposed scheme achieves an up-to 18.9x matching time speed-up over a state-of-the-art baseline while the storage size is up-to 3.4x smaller. 

We have proposed a privacy-aware document retrieval scheme with a two-level inverted index structure. It is an open problem how to retrieve matched documents and their features without leaking statistical access patterns when accessing a search index. Without relying on the hardware-assisted trusted execution environment, our two-level inverted index structure groups posting records with bucket tags so that run-time processing can produce query-specific tags in order to gather features of matched documents. To thwart leakage-abuse attacks, our design minimizes the chance that a server identifies document sharing across posting lists through index inspection or across-query association. Our evaluation shows that the proposed optimization for online query processing can achieve up to 131x processing time speedups compared to a state-of-the-art baseline. The proposed guided padding can effectively thwart leakage-abuse attacks that exploit word co-occurrence information to recover the plaintext of words.

This project also has investigated related fast information retrieval algorithms in multi-stage top-k search.  To effectively prune low-scoring documents in disjunctive query processing, our work proposes a boosting approach that further accelerates document retrieval on a sequence of posting windows in an inverted index with an order prioritized to tighten the lower bound of top k document rank scores earlier. This optimization could add benefits to safely eliminate more unnecessary operations involved in index block visitation and document rank score evaluation.    Our experiment finds that the proposed fast retrieval technique with window navigation can significantly reduce the query time for short queries with 2 and 3 terms, and a certain range of k values. Considering that the average number of words in queries of popular search engines is between 2 and 3, the proposed technique can be very effective for a search engine which deploys a large number of disjoint index partitions and when k does not need to be large for each individual partition that contributes part of top results. 

This project has further studied the time and space efficiency in transformer-based neural  ranking such as BERT during online document search. Following a late interaction architecture with pre-computed contextual token representations, we have proposed a compact representation for contextual token embeddings of documents called Contextual Quantization (CQ). Specifically, it adopts codebook-based quantization to compress embeddings while explicitly decoupling the ranking contributions of document specific and document-independent information in contextual embeddings. Our evaluation with ColBERT based document re-ranking shows that CQ can effectively reduce the storage space of a multi-vector document representation. For example, it uses about 10.2GB with 14x space reduction for 8.8 million MS MARCO passages and a small relevance degradation compared to the latest version of ColBERT.   

To run a transformer based neural ranking efficiently on a CPU-only platform, we have proposed a composite re-ranking scheme called BECR that combines deep contextual token interactions and traditional lexical term-matching features. In particular, BECR exploits a token encoding mechanism to decompose the query representations into pre-computable unigrams and skip-n-grams. By applying token encoding on top of a dual-encoder architecture, BECR separates the attentions between a query and a document while capturing the contextual semantics of a query.  As a result, BECR is fast on a CPU server, yet still able to achieve a competitive ranking relevance. 

Funding of this EAGER grant has supported our research to secure a regular NSF grant.  During the project period, PI has taught graduate and undergraduate courses on information retrieval, high performance computing, and has advised a number of PhD, master, and undergraduate students on related research projects. PI has also advised the computing projects of high school students.
